awd_titl_txt: NSF I-Corps Proposal: Elongated Instrument Cleaner
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is improvements in instrumentation for laparoscopic surgery. During surgery, scope vision may become impaired, requiring scope removal from the body and economic and medical disadvantages. Our technology helps mitigate the need of scope removal from the body by providing a cleaning mechanism. The commercial potential for this technology appears valid at this stage, with broad opportunity to address an established market need.

This I-Corps project focuses on a technology that can be pictured as a tube, shaft, or long arm with a squeegee at its tip. Its main purpose is to serve as a cleaning mechanism for the far end of an elongated instrument. The intellectual merit of this technology allows for the exploration of cleaning technology application surrounding elongated instruments, with particular opportunity in the medical field. At this stage, proof of concept has been demonstrated with functional prototypes that show acceptable performance. There is particular use for applications where the elongated instrument is constrained within a narrow and/or deep cavity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The major goal of this I-Corps project was to establish the product-market fit of an elongated instrument cleaner technology developed in the Medical Device Lab at UT-Austin.  We hypothesized that this technology could be of value to laparoscopic surgeons, their patients, and the insurance companies who pay for these surgeries.

During the team's participation in the NSF I-Corps program, many crucial aspects of the potential product-market fit in the United States were brought to light over the course of the team's 100 total customer interviews. The major customer segments interviewed included surgeons, public and private reimbursement organizations (insurance companies), medical device manufacturers/distributors, and hospital procurement and billing experts.

The I-Corps program provided all participants an overview of entrepreneurship training and business model planning.

This project provided education to all members of the team, both project specific technology-market fit, and general entrepreneurship education.

This project provided information about market opportunities that were communicated to the UT- Office of Technology Commercialization which  successfully licensed this technology to the startup company (Clearcam) founded by the I-Corps team members.  All the I-Corps team members are still involved with Clearcam, and several are primarily employed by Clearcam. 

This technology has shown the ability to improve surgeon vision during laparoscopic procedures which translates to improved surgical outcomes for patients and lower overall costs to payers.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2022
Modified by: Christopher G Rylander
